title: Q5: Question 5
content: What acoustic phenomenon occurs when two identical sound waves are played 180 degrees out of phase?

answers.text: The sounds completely cancel each other out resulting in absolute silence
The pitch drops by one octave

expert_explanation: When the peak of one wave aligns exactly with the trough of another identical wave, they add up to zero air pressure change. This is called complete phase cancellation.

expert_quote.text: Perfect phase cancellation is the fundamental mathematical secret behind how modern active noise-canceling headphones work.
expert_quote.author: Audio Engineer

explanation:

title: Q6: Question 6
content: According to the 'Inverse Square Law', if you double your distance from a direct sound source, what happens to the sound pressure level?

answers.text: It drops by 6dB (losing 75% of acoustic energy)

expert_explanation: The Inverse Square Law states that sound energy spreads out over a larger spherical area. Doubling distance means energy is spread over four times the area, a 6dB drop.

expert_quote.text: Moving a microphone from 1 foot to 2 feet away from a singer loses 6dB of volume. Understanding the inverse square law is crucial.
expert_quote.author: Studio Engineer

explanation:
Explanation: The Inverse Square Law states that sound energy spreads out over a larger spherical area. Doubling distance means energy is spread over four times the area, a 6dB drop.

- Studio Engineer

title: Q7: Question 7
content: What does the acoustic scientific measurement 'RT60' calculate?

answers.text: The exact time in seconds it takes for a sound's reverberation to decay by 60 decibels
The ratio between analog tape and digital conversion

expert_explanation: RT60 represents the time required for reflections of a direct sound to decay by 60 dB. Optimal control rooms usually aim for a short, tight RT60 around 0.3 seconds.

expert_quote.text: If a control room's RT60 is too long, the reverb of the room will completely smear the transients of the mix you are working on.
expert_quote.author: Acoustician

title: Q8: Question 8
content: What is a 'Standing Wave' (or Room Mode) in an acoustic recording space?

answers.text: A pure sine wave played continuously
A stationary acoustic wave pattern created when low frequencies bounce between parallel walls, causing massive volume peaks and nulls
The sound of a crowd standing and cheering
A wave that travels vertically from floor to ceiling only

expert_explanation: When the wavelength of a specific low frequency perfectly matches the dimensions between two parallel walls, it bounces back onto itself and creates stationary 'hot' and 'cold' spots of bass volume.

expert_quote.text: Standing waves will lie to you. They will make you think your mix has too much bass when standing in a corner, but no bass when sitting in the center.
expert_quote.author: Acoustic Designer
